msDesc.head: Letter from Maria Edgeworth to Frances Anne Edgeworth, Deep Dene, April 17, 1819

editorialDecl.p: Edgeworth’s spelling and punctuation are retained in transcription, including non-standard spelling, line breaks, and hyphenation of words. The long s and ligatured forms are silently emended.

div.p:
Deep Dene - Dene a saxon word meaning
a deep rift in a wood - in
short a deep dingle -

My dearest mother. Your wish that
we should be at Deep Dene is accom-
-plished accomplished . We are at last at this beautiful
place in this sweet valley of Dorking. Not
as we had last year hoped to be, with the
great and good Sir Samuel Bonnelly but
still we are with hospitable and kind
people and in the midst of all the
luxuries of life - and all that the gilding
and painting, and bronzing of art can
do within, and all that Nature can
do with hill and vale, dingle and
bushy wood to make the owners and
their guests happy.

The first evening of our arrival we
were so late that even in driving thro'
the vale of Dorkingwe were in an agony
that prevented our enjoyment. We were
cross because we were late. The Carrs who
are enthusiasts about the beauties of
the vale of Dorking& who know nothing
of the Hopes but that he has built a great
new brick house and pulled down a
some old house in Chart park which very
loved had spoken with sufficient in-
-dignation indignation of the manufactory looking
brick edifice which they say has set the valley
on fire - At first sight the offices & the
house all irregularly joined with archways & cupola's
and strangenesses of red brick certainly did
strike us as frightful in the midst of
a most beautiful country - Our friend
the housekeeper & several footmen standing
at the arched door way watching in the dusk
for our arrival, and the first words in
answer to mine of " Is it dinner time? "
" Yes Ma'am - dinner has been waiting
this hour " - increased my uncomforta ble uncomfortable feelings - Fanny was so much tired
that we determined she should not go to
dinner especially as we heard that
Con-
versation Conversation Sharp and some other gentlemen
were here. I had taken it for granted that
the Hopes dined at the same hour in Town
and country. But instead of 7 they dine
at 6 in the country & various operations
& leave takings & a visit to Lord - I mean
to Lady Carrington had altogether detained
us too late in Town - Fanny's health & the
pity and interest which it and she ex-
cited excited stood us in good stead. We dressed
in the utmost hurry skurry in less than
five minutes I am sure made our appear
ance in the drawing where luckily the
circle were standing & sitting by dim fire
light & our guilty faces could scarcely
be seen - From the midst two black & white figures whom
I knew to be Mr. & Mrs. Hope each with hand
extended came to meet us and with one
comfortable pressure of each hand set the
mind at ease. I descried by the wood
fire light the wooden cut of Mr. Sharpe's
face and was re-introduced to a Mr. Harness
whom you may remember tho' I did
not - He told me he was introduced to us first
at Lydia White's just after we had been pre-
sented presented to the Duchess
Qn of Sussex. - He is an agreeable
man & Mr. Sharpe was what they call (and
I hate the expression) in great force that day
- And there was an admirable dinner
of all manner of well disguised French
dishes and creams & soufflés and ices
and more than would have sufficed for the
dinner of the first bon vivant in Town was
sent by the goodnatured Mr Hopes to Fanny
- As soon as I could steal away after dinner
I got to her & found her as pale as a turnip
wrapped in my shawl. After having swal
lowed a little jelly she went to bed - A most
comfortable large French mattress - Canopy
bed- large enough for four such as she
& I - three rooms opening into one another
- Small but superbly furnished - I was
cross even with the fine furniture that
night & regretted the dear Carrs & the
the home comforts we found there.
- I was shockingly afraid that Fanny
was going to be ill again here - She had
but little sleep in the night- and in the
morning a new misery! Honora wakened
with one of her sad sick headaches- Impos
sible Impossible that either of them could think of get-
ting getting up to break fast. But there was one
comfort. Mr. and Mrs. Hope a breakfast in
their own room. Only Miss Burrowes
(Mrs. Hopes niece) and Mr. Harness were at
the breakfast table - This whole first day
was uncomfortable as you may guess
But this day all is bright and well
& bright and happy . Honora and Fanny
are both refitted & we have had charm-
ing charming walks & drives . Fanny first was
taken out in the a carriage & then had a
little walk with Mr Hope and me -
a beautiful walk through the deep dene!
-Larch & young beech just come out?.-
& grass as green & fresh as Erin's - birds
singing - lambs feeding & soft April air every
182
thing to delight Fanny going out for the
first walk after her illness - she fixed on a
beautiful place for a seat which Mr Hope
says he will have there & will call Fanny's
seat. Nothing can be more courteously kind
than Mr. and Mrs. Hope are to us. I am very glad
to see that her looks have improved much
within this last fortnight & her spirits
are better - But she has too little to do and
too many real good & fine things & too
much time to think over painful recol-
lections recollections . Her living children are both fine
boys and they will in time I hope re-ani-
mate re-animate her.

Mr Hope keeps up in my mind the opinion
I early formed - not of his taste, for I think
his taste is the worst part of his mind, but
of his information & general powers of
conversation . In a very long tete a tete walk
I had with him he gave me a history of the
progress of architecture so perfectly clear
that it might have been written down
as he spoke it and your dear father & Louisa
w. have admired it and Leslie Foster with
all his memory and all his accuracies
could have found no fault. The most
entertaining part of the conversation how-
ever however was on persons not things. You may
judge of the degree of our intimacy when I
tell you that Mr. H related to me the whole
history of his love courtship & marriage
and moreover of Miss Berry's courtship of him
- disappointment - anger - and quarrel with
Mrs. Hope - All which I must reserve for
future fireside conversations - One detached anecdote how
ever I am afraid of forgetting & it is too good to forget
When Mr. H was a young man & Captn. in the Mary
bone volunteers he was at a city dinner, at his Colonels . a young
lady sister to the lady of the house sat beside him at dinner
- He was shy & she was shy & not a word passed between
them during the first course but towards
the end of the second the young lady as it
is supposed feeling it incumbent upon her
to do the honors of her sisters house & to say
something to the young stranger & recollecting
that he was just returned from his travels &
that he had been in at Constantinople she softly
hemmed several times & at last the first sound
of her voice he heard in this question
"Pray Sir how many concubines has the Grand
"Seignior?"

Mr. Hope was so entertaining during this walk that
it was as much as I could do to enjoy the beauties
of nature. But so beautiful a walk & with such
variety of beauty I never had in my life: & my
companion judiciously refrained from point
ing out beauties or forcing admiration from me
- He gently turned or stopped when we came to
any delightful point of view but that was all.
-And after a long walk one day he took Fanny
& me again over the part which I had liked the
best to shew it to her. Nothing can be more obliging
& kind than he is to us.- I dare not attempt
any description of grounds or country . all I
can say is that I hope you will some time see
them for yourself & that my present pleasure
is incomplete for want of your sharing it
my dearest mother & friend - I long also to
have my aunt Ruxton with me - But one can-
not have every thing - Tiresome old Truism
that
which meets one at every turn in life

This house is in its present condition
frightful scarcely handsome in its external
appearance. The stable at the bottom of the hill
looks like a vast square brick manufactory. The
house like some of the views of in Athenian Stewart
of Turkish buildings qrotesque & confused among trees
in no one particular taste & bend in glaring in red brick
instead of stone or marble Mr. Hope assures me
many churches in Lombardy in particular
that the a famous church in Milan Santa Maria della Grazie is of red brick
- I am sorry for it - and I am glad that he in-
tends intends next year to stucco this house & to take
off the reproach from himself of having set the valley
5 183
on fire"
This house is magnificently furnished
but to my taste much too fine for a country house
even putting the idea of comfort out of the question.
-There is too much Egyptian ornament Egyptian
hierogliphic figures bronze & gilt but all hideous
In one room called the Egyptian room there is a
bed made exactly after the model of Denon's
Egyptian bed - a sofa bed broad enough for two
aldermen two figures, in a kneeling posture, drawn facing away from a figure of Osiris, with two flourishes beneath embossed gold hiero
glyphic hieroglyphic
frights all pointing with
their hands distorted backwards
at an Osiris or a long armed
monster of some sort who sits after their fashion
on their her hams & heels and hath the likeness of
a globe of gold on her lappetted, scaly lappetted
head. - In another room there is a really
curious collection of Raphaels designs of orna
ments ornaments for the Vatican - from Titus's baths. some
-thing something like those at Lord Sanderlins. How could
Raphaels genius turn to such conceits - for instance branches
of trees with groups of singing birds knocking an
owl.- - I should never finish or should make
a description fit for an auctioneer if I went
through all these rooms. The French furniture
is rich & beautiful mahogany vaineered more
exquisitely & showing in better taste the veins
& knots of the wood than any English workman
ship workmanship I ever saw. but all with clumsy keep as
you saw in Paris - In every passage & hall
there are collections of frightful monsters in
bronze or stone or plaister - one bronze genuis
as I am told he is, about my own height with
outstretched long arms offends me most, because
I am obliged to come across him ten times a day
in passing to my own door. I could with plea-
sure pleasure knock him down & break him to pieces.

Private
[The first night I came here the impudent monster
[kept me a quarter of an hour prisoner in the
[water closet because I mistook his shadow for the
[shadow of a real man standing near the door. do you
wonder I owe him a grudge?]

- -There are sundry mechanical impossibilities too
in some of the statues which hurt my mechanical
feelings for instance a resigned female Cariatides whose
of white stucco whose head in eternal pillory supports
a heavy stair case while her feet stand on a globe so
small that it never could support her & it seems al-
ways always stepping from under her - also a slice of a bronze A candalabra figure
in the dining room
with a woman holding up twelve candle branches with a small square base arms painfully holding 12 candle branches
heavier & larger than herself and without a resting
place for her poor feet - on the contrary with
a cruel gold basket hung on her ancles ! -
But most I feel for a classical figure
never so used before to my knowledge - The slave tak-
ing taking the thorn out of his foot a cast in bronze on
a pedestal but the pedestal so small that the leg
on which the thorny foot is crossed has no support
but sticks out in mid air - an eternally painful
impossibility that hurts my eyes whenever I go
into the dining room .
There are some beautiful things however - for instance
two casts of Canova's heads of Perseus and of Paris
and a Psyche of Torvalsen's - By the by that Danish
stone cutter has jilted the highborn Scotchwoman
the Miss McKinzie who fell in love with him - He
found that her fortune was not equal to his expecta
tions expectations & he has set off for Iceland - one way of curing
a lady's love -
We have had no company here but two or three
gentlemen Mr. Harness - agreeable & open hearted -
Mr. Moore son of the late Archbishop of Canterbury
clever - but too much of the Poco Curante for me - but
not for the fashion - squinting a little & with a mouth
that opens crookedly [figur5e] and lips that express scorn
but a cela prés very agreeable and high bred - And
fond of his own comforts as Lambeth could make him!
-of Mr. Sharpe I need say nothing you know him &
his magic lantern of good things - Some new figures
on the slides - Miss Burrowes Mrs. Hopes niece has
been the only femal we have seen tho Lady Rothus
& others called but we escaped from them - Miss
Burrowes has been well mastered & has travelled
& all that but is but an insipid personnage with
a flat back & well curled hair - she can tell a little
about Florence but all her words & movements are
so measured that I long to shake her to see if I could
184
shake the affectation out of her to satisfy myself whe-
ther whether there is or is not any thing else within her. She
always moves with her toe pointed down on the
carpet and as if she was winning her way between
brittle glass or precious china and moving, or stand-
-ing standing , or sitting she seems evermore as if she had
the fear of the five positions before her eyes - "Bend
poor thing! as Mrs. Candor would say, Who knows
but she thinks it her duty - and the whole duty of
woman - But Mr Hopeaa really likes her and says that
though a spoiled child she is not the least selfish
A whole family of rich & good quakers, the Barclays,
are to dine here tomorrow - I have made inquiries
for the man who married an Irish young lady
of the name of Sanderson & have asked for him
by the name of Slater and of Turner, and have
looked over the list of Book society names for any
other name that sounded likely but all in vain!
So I must give up looking by your blind direction
my dears for a needle in a bundle of hay.
Sunday morng.
Now to matters of more interest than
all this scandal against statues and human
creations - Fanny has her own color in her cheeks
this morning & looks better after a nights good sleep
than I have seen her since she came to England
- Mrs. Hope ha She has no cough - no pain in her
side - Some appetite & is going to ride for more .
- Mrs. Hope has lent her a habit & a stumbling
poney .- It is a fine sunshiny shining day & Heaven
speed her - I am a little frightened - but I believe
without reason . She is going to ride with Master Henry Hope who rides well & is good natured
I have full instructions from Dr. Holland
respect-
ing respecting every particular about her health. He says
that for 2 or 3 years till it becomes regularly good
her health will require care - but with care he
fears nothing
Private [Now I am between two fears - Fear the 1st. that you
[should think Fannys illness has been too expensive
[to me - Fear the 2d. that you should apprehend
[that Dr. Holland has not been fee-d and that your
[Fanny has been left under the weight of this obliga-
[tion obligation to her young admiring physician - No my dear mother
[that last I could not do - So I had better set your mind
[ease by telling you the simple truth. I found it very
[difficult to make him take a fee the first day -
[but did - one guinea - I never repeated the attempt till
[the last moment at Mrs. J Baillies - He eluded me
[wondrous well - but I was too cunning - followed
[him down stairs when he thought he was clear off - called
[him back to ask another question about Fanny - He
[came running back with all zeal good easy man!
[You wish that I should let you know when we
[return to Lady E W's at Kensington
[Oh certainly = Then I will do so upon one
[condition & upon no other "- great & real reluctance
[upon his part but I conquered & leaving a five pound
[note on his cuff for I cd. not force it into his hand ran
[up stairs - Upon consulting Francis since I fear
[it was not enough - I understand that a guinea a
[mile when a phys goes out of Town is the usual
[rate - But when we go to Lady EW without telling
[what has been done I will inquire what should be
[done - and it shall be all right - The apothecary
[bill was very little only £2 - and now my
[dear mother I hope you do not grudge me this
[much - Fanny dear Fanny does not.
If you will permit me to give you
my unasked advice about little Francis's 5 weeks,
Whit
suntide Whitsuntide holidays I should advise his staying with
his uncle Francis & his friends in Harley Street
instead of going with the Beddoes to Bath. Anna
is as kind as kind can be & I am sorry to rob her
fraudulently & as it were underhand of the great
pleasure I know she would have in being good
to the boy & to your son; but I have my reasons
for thinking that Tom is not the best companion
for him and in Bath there would be danger of
Francis being spoiled - Francis & Mr. Wilson seem
to me both of them to understand how to treat
a boy - If they go to Epping there is a work shop &
employment out of doors - If they stay in Town
They will take Francis frequently to Mr Carrs
- Joanna Bailie's & Mr. Colebrooks at Hampstead
- The Carrs in particular are an admirable literary acquaintance
6 185
for him - Colebrook's scientific - and Joanna & Agnes
Bail
lie Baillie all that is good & motherly - and all these
people judiciously fond of the boy - And all
have cordially invited him - And the object of
taking him there will draw the acquaintance
between our Hampstead & Harley Street friends
necessarily closer together - an advantage to all
parties concerned - Now dear mother give
me a decided answer as soon as you can
say whether you chuse that he shd. go to Bath or
to Captn. B - for Whitsuntide is a-coming
He goes to the Carrs & Baillies on the
22d. for the 3 days Easter Holidays - I told Mrs.
Marcet you would give him some leave to go to see
her. She asked leave very humbly to send for him some Saturday
- I asked Dr. M to shew him his model of a steam
engine next next this Sunday & have settled that his uncle
will takes him there . I believe I told you in my last
that excellent answer Fs. made to Mr. Carr about
the steam engine - If I did not say so - for it is
but just you shd. know how sensible & how modest that dear boy
is - Mr. Hope runs up to Town tomorrow & down next day &
We shall stay here till next saturday morning
the 24th. when we shall go to Lady E. Whitbread -
I enclose a note from Lady Harrowby - shall
accept her offer and if Fanny is stout as a lion
she shall go with me for it was for her chiefly
I mana begged the favor & I would not take
the trouble of going without her -
When we are again with Lady E W you
know she has promised me to have her brother
Lord Gray that we may introduce little Francis
to him. I particularly wish this because Lord G
is excessively fond of his own sons who are fine
clever boys & therefore he will take to Francis &
once in Francis will never be out of his head &
heart - Besides I wish for Francis to become
acquainted with the Gray boys - (not Gray Beards)
- They will be right good companions for him
when he visits Lady EW W - instead of the Battys who
tho good are vulgarish & worship him too much
Too Besides I know old good Lady Gray will
hug him to her breast (bone) when she knows
him & all the Gray children cluster & cling
round that Eldest of Forms
Your commissions are all executed &
I have bought 30 yards of Canvas (Italian
gauze for gowns for the Young Curs Lord
send you & they may like the color .- and
I have bought ribbons for bonnets & belts -
Gillore!- -
Farewell Mr. Hope calls me to walk
G Bristow in full feather - with a new
coat - Mrs. Hogan the housekeeper calls
him " That old gentleman of yours who is
walking always about the grounds - Tell
Molly - Love to Kitty - Hate to all
my other inquiring friends
I rejoice in all the dear Sheriff's glories
& we were infinitely pleased with your
account of them - read to Sneyd & Harriette
- both well & well pleased - all smooth
as velvet - I left them directions to go to
see Lady Farnham - & gave them a note
to Miss Fox & Miss Vernon

postscript.p:
1h after 5 o clock - Just returned from a
most beautiful walk with Mr. Hope -
I have used the word Beautiful! in so
many different tones of admiration within this
last hour that I have am afraid I have almost
worn it out - So I will let it rest as I am
instructed to let the Galvanic battery Miss
Seebright gave me, rest whenever it is tired
that it may recover its power to act -
186
10) Pray tell Sophy Ruxton all about Lord
Carrington &our intention of going to High
Wycombe the 1st. of May - She says she is sur
prised surprised that I do not mention Lord C-
Bless her I have not time to mention
half the people &things I ought to mention
- I could not write to her this moment if
unless you would cut me in bits &give
me two heads &4 2 right hands .- When I can only
write to one you dearest mother have
the first claim of affection duty &gratitude
- Lucky &pleasant when all those
three go together . I never can thank you
enough for lending me Fanny - You
shall soon have her back again I hope
the better in health &in happiness for
her journey .
She has just come in from her poney
ride &liked it. -------------
But here I was interrupted by
a dreadful disaster - Enter Mrs. Hope. Hope
came softly stealing into the little room
where we were all three writing and
in her hand she held a superb Mala- -chite Malachite necklace and cross with gold chains!
- Oh mother I admired a piece of malachite
in a marble table the other day &Mr. Hope
explained to me that there is only one
mine of it in the world in Russia
And Mrs. Hope. Hope has given me
this necklace! and I could not refuse
her lips trembled so &she was in such
agitation about it - When I said
Fanny is well - she has ridden out almost
every day on a nice little poney with Henry
Hope on a ditto &a servant on a prancing
chesnut like Wat Tyler .- I would not
let Mr. Harness, who much desired it, ride
with them instead of the servant on said
prancing horse because I am told he is
a bad rider &I should have been in an
agony the whole time - besides the real
danger - Yesterday we went in the carriage
and Fanny rode to see Wootton . Mr.
Evelyns most beautiful place - Woods
worthy of Sylva indeed! - The distance
from Deep Dene about 3 1/2 four miles
- F rode there &back without fatigue
- The whole ride delightful through lane
&village with every variety of landscape
&banks rich &gay, (better than rich
&rare) with primroses, violets, orchis
in profusion - White thorns &fruit
trees in full blossom - neat cottages &
old English country houses of all sizes
from noble to simple - The house at Wotton
is not pretty - but up &down old fashioned
and interesting from being Wotton with
all its traditions - We sent up to ask per-
mission permission to see the library &an old thin stupid
wizzan looking Mr. Evelyn received us with
good natured awkwardness - &told us we
were welcome to see whatever we pleased
- But he knew nothing about his ancestors
or their pictures by which he was surrounded
- all he could tell us was that there was a
portrait of Mr. Evelyn with his book in his hand
187
- and he did also know a portrait of Fellotson
- the library is not nearly so large as Edgeworth
town library nor so pleasant - More like
Brianstown - But filled with choice old
books - all growing damp - The oaf said -
" Aye here are more books here than I shall
"ever read I am sure - And there are some
"up there that never were down I dare say
"since they were put up -
He threw turned out some old prints
before us &old plans "Since you are curious
to see such things"
He was very civil &we were very
ungrateful for thinking him insufferably
stupid .
Mr. Harness is as far from stupid as possible
I like both Mr. Hs all three Hs much
Hope - Harness &Hitchings - - Mr. Harness
is one of the most natural characters
I ever saw &Mr. Hitchings an excellent
clergyman - both appear the more
amiable for liking each other as they do
I must go out - Mrs. Hope. Hope waiting
adieu - we have been very happy
here - Tomorrow by tea time at Grove house
ever affectionately your Scrawler Maria E.
